description: From French oblat and its source, post-classical Latin oblātus (“person dedicated to religious life”), a nominal use of the past participle of offerō (“I offer”).

entries.meaning: (Roman Catholicism) A person dedicated to a life of religion or monasticism, especially a member of an order without religious vows or a lay member of a religious community.
A child given up by its parents into the keeping or dedication of a religious order or house.

description: From Late Latin oblātus, from Latin ob (“in front of, before”) + lātus (“broad, wide”), (modeled after prōlātus (“extended, lengthened”)).

adjectives.description: oblate (comparative more oblate, superlative most oblate)

entries.meaning: Flattened or depressed at the poles.
examples: The Earth is an oblate spheroid.

verbs.description: oblate (third-person singular simple present oblates, present participle oblating, simple past and past participle oblated)

entries.meaning: To offer as either a gift or an oblation.
